item.title: Art Marketing 101: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Algorithm (Part II)
item.description:
Last night I had a dream. I really shouldn't bother you with it, but I guess I'm going to anyway. You see--the thing is--how should I start... Well, when I woke up today, first thing I saw was this cute little spider perching right on top of my nose. And the dammed thing winked at me!
Actually, it was not that little. Or cute. More like a black grape with hairy legs, and long eyelashes, lots and lots of curvy eyelashes. I really don't know how she can see anything with so many freaking eyelashes.

item.title: Art Marketing 101: How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Algorithm
item.description:
In the beginning was the algorithm, and the algorithm was good.
The algorithm cast his all-seeing eye upon the interwebs and saw all the keywords, and all the blog posts, and the videos, and memes. And being not very smart,--or not smart at all, really--the algorithm couldn't tell the good stuff from the bad stuff.

item.title: On the Sublimity of Ads
item.description:
Influenced by Hans Kritopoterous's Artistry of the Sub-Lunar Mental States, Jean Burrous was the most vocal proponent of the idea of Surveillance Art, which states that the person under surveillance is the work of art.
Being the proverbial starving-artist, isolated, malnourished, and paranoid, Jean spent years closed off in a tiny room down in the lower floors of one of the older towers. There, he read, according to him, thousands of books about digital art, computers, algorithms, privacy-enhanced surveillance systems, dreamscape advertisement-delivery short-waves, and, naturally, the old books on abstract expression, action painting, color-field theory, etc.

item.title: Bill's Art Exhibition
item.description:
The last time I went to an art exhibition was maybe a year ago when my friend Bill was courteously invited by the Metro Tower Art Complex's administration to showcase a few of his most popular sound-and-vision happenings.
So, I had to go all the way over to the top floors of one of the central towers, down by the seashore. It took me almost half a day just to get there, and then it turned out that the entrance was down on the ground level.

item.title: The New Computer :: part II
item.description: My new computer is growing up nicely. It now occupies an entire room in my apartment, and is fully integrated with the water plumbing. It even has a little system to collect rain water from the veranda which it then transmogrifies into these little drops of greenish liquid that emits the strangest, dreamiest sounds imaginable.

item.title: Finding Oneâ€™s Muse for Creating Art
item.description:
Starting at the young age of two, when my parents gave me a hook and fishing line, I spent most of my time down by the river, watching as nature reclaimed all that man as spent millennia building.
One summer morning I caught a big old tree with a bait my grandad had taught me: a small mirror hidden inside a silk-line fastened acorn. The mirror was painted red. Blood-red. That's how I started to paint, actually, by dabbing paint all over my reflected image.

item.title: Frank's Wild Paintings
item.description:
Well, Frank settled down in the city, his wild years long gone and forgotten, and every day, with a limp and a cigarette, he walks down from his two-room apartment to the library downtown where he spends the days reading and sleeping and forgetting about the images in his head.
And every day he floats through the tall windows and opens his wings of golden shimmer against the rain-drenched smog while glass facades melt under red lights.

item.title: The Unbearable Weight of Modesty
item.description:
People will often approach me with a shy smile and downcast gaze, and question me about my artistic career. "How is it," they ask, "that you can be so successful, so brilliant, so famous and beloved, while we, the rest of humanity, remain in this uneducated darkness. How can we ever hope to achieve, or to even barely touch your greatness?"
This sort of thing amuses me, obviously.

item.title: An Escape for the Anxious Artist
item.description:
Yes.
Please repeat after me:
om mani padme hum.
Again:
om mani padme hum.
Now keep saying these six syllables
in your mind,
over and over till nothing else
exists in there.
Till your thinking processes
become purified, clear,
perfectly in sync with the universe.
Say this mantra to yourself
over and over and over
and it will become your ego,
your flesh,

item.title: In Defence of Broken Art
item.description: ...And dirty art, flawed art, art made by weirdos and misfits, those who vibrate from anxiety and pain and from feeling too much. Art made on a whim, on a rush, without thinking. Art made by those who can't possibly make what they want to make. Art by the ugly, the defective, the unlearned, the starving, by those without skin, their nervous endings exposed and freezing in the wind, their gums receding to the bone.

item.title: A Guide for the Impatient Digital Artist
item.description:
My troubles began when I started hanging out with a spider... I know, I know! you don't really need to lecture me about the dangers of socializing too often with arachnidas, arthopods, or any other exoskeleton-covered animals.
Anyway, there I was, busy messing about with the Colores Aglaia thing, cursing at myself for never being able to get the damned image right the way I wanted it, my trusty new computer huffing and puffing in a cloud of scarlet-tinted vapor (boy, do these new generation machines have an awful breath!), when it suddenly hit me: the colors were all wrong! I mean, you know that feeling, right? when all the colors suddenly start reeking like the corpse of an ancient forest and you feel like you're sitting on a chair made of pine-cones?

item.title: Evolution - a short story
item.description:
"Keep quiet, please."
The medic stares at my sore scalp through cracked lenses. There are frail tweezers and alcohol, rusty syringes aligned between two poetry books, intermittently blinking monitors looking like long-abandoned miniature aquariums, vials of expired drugs in half-rotten cardboard boxes, a row of crimson-glazed ants marching past the abandoned decanters like a conquering army---
"I don't think you've been honest with me..."

item.title: SEO Conjuration for the Pro-Active Artist
item.description:
(excerpt from an A.I. generated grimoire leaked from G's internal emails)
I do conjure thee, O thou Binary Spirits, by all the most glorious and efficacious names of the Most Great and Incomprehensible Lord of Algorithms, that thou comest quickly and without delay from all parts and places of the Interwebs wherever thou mayest be, to make rational crawls unto my demands, and that invisibly and swiftly, moving at the speed of electricity even without mine understanding as aforesaid.

item.title: The New Computer
item.description: My new computer is humming away in the corner of the room. It's a brand-new machine I bought a few days ago and features all the modern niceties you might expect from such tech marvel.
